scenarios.text: Welcome to Alex’s world. It’s day one of the new chapter, and the rent envelope sits on the kitchen counter like a ticking clock. Two opportunities are calling—time to pick one and see where it leads.
Alex stands at a crossroads this month. The old routine is behind them, and two very different paths stretch ahead—one in the quiet hum of a warehouse, the other in the glow of late-night screens.
The email from HR lands with a thud: ‘Payroll on hold—we need your ID verification.’ It’s that moment every new employee knows is coming but still dreads.
scenarios.details: Putting it off just means delayed paychecks and awkward follow-up emails. In the modern gig economy, everyone wants to see those documents.

choices.label: Hand over the documents and get it done
Maybe tomorrow… (postpone)
choices.requireModal: Alex tries to put it off, but there’s no getting around it—verification is the only path to getting paid.

scenarios.text: Life can’t just be work and sleep on repeat. Alex scrolls through options: a streaming bundle for {{streamingCost}}/month promises endless stories and escapes, while a bowling league at {{bowlingCost}}/month offers real people, flying pins, and the smell of lane wax.
scenarios.details: One’s a cozy couch ritual. The other’s Thursday nights with strangers who might become friends.

scenarios.text: But wait—there’s more to life than just one hobby. A community garden plot just opened up, promising dirt under the fingernails and homegrown tomatoes. Meanwhile, a D&D group is recruiting for their next campaign, complete with dice-rolling drama and epic quests.,,{options:[{key:gardening
Morning disaster: the toaster sparks like a tiny firework show, then goes silent forever. Alex stares at their un-toasted bread.
scenarios.details: There’s the sensible option—grab something cheap and functional. Or there’s the fantasy option—a gleaming, feature-packed model that’ll make breakfast feel like an event.

choices.label: Treat yourself to the fancy model

scenarios.text: The week dissolves in a blur of routines and small victories. Sunday evening arrives with that familiar feeling—another week down, another week ahead.
Days blend together like watercolors. Coffee, work, home, sleep, repeat. Then suddenly it’s Friday again, and Alex wonders where the time went.
The conversation nobody wants to have finally happens. Alex and their partner sit across from each other, and both know what’s coming. It’s not dramatic—just sad, necessary, and final.
There’s this person at the climbing gym. They always seem to be on the wall at the same time as Alex, and their smile is genuine when they suggest grabbing tea sometime.

A friend’s been playing matchmaker. ‘You two would totally click,’ they insist, showing Alex photos of someone who apparently loves indie films and obscure coffee shops. There’s a number to text, if Alex wants to.

The boss pulls Alex aside with good news: ‘We want you as team lead. It’s {{raise}} more per month.’ There’s a handshake waiting—but also late nights, difficult conversations, and the weight of other people’s mistakes.
scenarios.details: More money, more stress. The classic trade-off.

scenarios.text: A recruiter slides into Alex’s inbox with an offer: {{raise}} more per month at a competitor. The catch? It’s across town, the corporate culture is notoriously rigid, and the commute will eat an hour each way.
scenarios.details: The money’s tempting, but is it worth the trade-off?

incidentEvents.story: Alex’s phone slips from their pocket in slow motion, landing screen-first in a puddle. The screen goes dark, and no amount of rice is bringing it back to life.
That nagging toothache finally sends Alex to the dentist, who delivers the bad news with a sympathetic grimace: root canal time. The bill arrives a week later like a painful echo.

Alex comes home to find half the furniture gone and a note on the counter: ‘Sorry, had to bounce early—family emergency.’ No forwarding address, no last month’s utilities split, just empty space and awkward silences.
The car makes a horrible grinding sound and coasts to a stop. The mechanic’s diagnosis? Transmission failure. Alex’s heart sinks faster than their bank balance.
The laptop won’t turn on. Alex tries everything—different outlets, different chargers, prayers to the tech gods. Nothing. A genius bar appointment confirms it’s dead for good.
Someone cut through Alex’s bike lock and made off with the ride. All that’s left is a sad piece of cable on the sidewalk and a sinking feeling.
A slip on wet stairs sends Alex to urgent care. Nothing’s broken, but the X-rays, the doctor’s time, and the awkward crutch rental add up fast.
Water starts pooling in the kitchen at 11 PM. By midnight, the emergency plumber is there, shaking their head at the burst pipe. By 2 AM, Alex is staring at the invoice in disbelief.
Alex’s cat gets into something toxic and needs emergency vet care. The night is sleepless, the outcome is thankfully good, but the bill is absolutely not.
Two parking tickets appear on the windshield within the same week. Alex swears the signs weren’t clear, but the city doesn’t care about interpretations.

goodEvents.text: The night market is staging something special this weekend: a neon drone show synchronized to live music, plus hands-on creative workshops. Alex could use a dose of electric wonder for {{cost}}.
A pop-up experimental cooking lab invites Alex to experience a five-course tasting menu paired with hands-on lessons. It’s molecular gastronomy meets dinner theater for {{cost}}.
A VR art collective is hosting a mindfulness residency where participants paint in virtual space while guided through meditation. The future is weird and wonderful, and it costs {{cost}}.
A lakefront yoga retreat has one spot left for their weekend intensive. Dawn sessions on the dock, sunset meditation, and the kind of peace Alex didn’t know they needed—all for {{cost}}.
An underground speakeasy is hosting a jazz and cocktail pairing night. Password required, vintage attire encouraged, and {{cost}} gets Alex through the hidden door.
A local theater troupe is staging an immersive mystery play where the audience solves the crime. Dinner included, suspense guaranteed, {{cost}} to play detective.
A storytelling slam invites Alex to share a 5-minute true story on stage—or just watch others bare their souls. Entry is {{cost}} and includes two drink tickets and a lot of courage.
An artisan chocolate maker is teaching a bean-to-bar workshop. Alex will roast, grind, and temper their own chocolate bar for {{cost}}, then probably eat it immediately.
A botanical garden is hosting a twilight lantern walk with live traditional music and tea ceremony demonstrations. The ticket costs {{cost}} and promises enchantment.
An indie film festival is screening rare international films all weekend. Alex can get an all-access pass for {{cost}} and disappear into other worlds.
A silent disco in the park lets participants dance with wireless headphones under the stars. Three DJ channels, zero noise complaints, {{cost}} to join the surreal party.
A pottery studio is hosting a ‘throw and sip’ night where Alex can make a bowl while enjoying wine and good company. Messy hands, creative minds, {{cost}} for the experience.
A local author is giving an intimate reading and Q&A at a cozy bookstore. Limited seats, signed books available, and {{cost}} includes coffee and conversation.
An outdoor adventure company is leading a moonlit kayak trip with bioluminescent plankton. Nature’s light show on the water for {{cost}}.
A rooftop cinema is screening cult classics with a live comedy commentary track. Bring blankets, expect laughter, {{cost}} for admission.
A vintage arcade is hosting a high score championship with prizes and glory. Entry is {{cost}} and includes unlimited play all night.
A botanical cocktail class teaches Alex to forage, mix, and muddle drinks using herbs and edible flowers. Sip your creations for {{cost}}.

badEvents.text: Alex wakes to a hissing sound and a growing puddle. The radiator has burst, spraying rusty water across the floor. The landlord’s number goes straight to voicemail.
The text arrives without warning: ‘I got the job—I’m moving across the country next week.’ A close friend, suddenly gone. The apartment feels quieter already.
The check engine light has been on for weeks, but now the car won’t start at all. The tow truck driver shakes their head knowingly. This is going to hurt.
Alex’s beloved childhood dog crosses the rainbow bridge after a long, good life. The vet is kind, the decision was right, but the house feels unbearably empty.
An unexpected tax bill arrives in the mail. Apparently Alex miscalculated something last year, and the IRS would like to discuss it. With penalties.
The upstairs neighbor’s bathtub overflows in the middle of the night, creating a waterfall through Alex’s ceiling. The landlord promises to fix it ‘eventually.’
Alex’s favorite coffee shop—the one with the perfect corner booth and the barista who knows their order—is closing permanently. A chain store is moving in.
Someone breaks into Alex’s car and steals the stereo, leaving shattered glass on the driver’s seat. Nothing else was taken, just the one thing that made commutes bearable.
The promotion Alex was promised goes to someone else—someone newer, with better connections. The explanation is corporate speak for ‘sorry, not sorry.’
A family member calls with bad news about a health diagnosis. Everything else suddenly feels trivial and far away.
The landlord announces a rent increase that’s technically legal but practically devastating. Alex has 60 days to decide: pay more or move.
Alex’s bike gets hit by a car while parked. The driver didn’t leave a note, just a crumpled frame and bent wheels.
A beloved pet gets sick suddenly. The emergency vet saves their life, but Alex’s savings account takes a critical hit.
The company announces layoffs. Alex survives the cut, but three close work friends don’t. Survivor’s guilt sets in during the awkward goodbye drinks.
Someone steals Alex’s package from the porch—the one with the birthday gift for their sibling. No insurance, no replacement, just disappointment.
The power goes out during a heatwave, and everything in the fridge spoils before the electricity comes back. The smell is unforgettable.
Alex discovers their identity was used to open a credit card. Hours on hold with fraud departments and credit bureaus follow.
A long-term relationship ends not with drama but with a tired conversation about growing apart. It’s mutual, it’s civil, and it’s absolutely heartbreaking.
The favorite local bookstore where Alex spent countless hours announces it’s closing. Another community space lost to rising rents.
A work project Alex poured months into gets cancelled due to ‘shifting priorities.’ All that effort, just gone.

hobbyOffers.text: A community ceramics studio just opened its doors, offering memberships for {{cost}}/month. The scent of wet clay and the promise of handmade mugs calls to Alex.
The neighborhood climbing gym drops its monthly rate to {{cost}}. Alex imagines the burn in their forearms and the view from the top of the wall.
A retro gaming club sends Alex an invite for {{cost}}/month. Unlimited arcade tokens, Friday night tournaments, and the glow of CRT screens await.
A poetry open mic night at the indie bookstore is recruiting regulars for {{cost}}/month. It includes a drink ticket and the courage to share words with strangers.
A woodworking workshop offers weekend access for {{cost}}/month. Alex pictures building a bookshelf, or at least learning not to fear the table saw.
A community choir is holding auditions—no experience necessary, just {{cost}}/month and a willingness to harmonize with strangers.
A photography club offers darkroom access and monthly photo walks for {{cost}}. Film photography is coming back, and Alex wants in.
An improv comedy troupe needs new members for {{cost}}/month. Awkward exercises, spontaneous scenes, and surprisingly deep friendships are part of the package.
A meditation and sound bath studio offers unlimited sessions for {{cost}}/month. Alex could use some intentional quiet in their life.
A cooking class collective runs weekly sessions for {{cost}}/month. Each week is a different cuisine, a different technique, and always too much delicious food.
A language exchange group meets weekly at a café for {{cost}}/month. Alex could finally learn Spanish, or Italian, or maybe just make friends who travel.
A vintage film society screens classics every Tuesday for {{cost}}/month. Think Criterion Collection on a big screen with other cinema nerds.
A community bike repair co-op offers membership for {{cost}}/month. Alex gets tools, workspace, and knowledge from folks who actually know what they’re doing.
A tabletop board game café offers unlimited play for {{cost}}/month. Every week brings new games, new strategies, and that particular kind of friendly competition.
A martial arts dojo opens enrollment for {{cost}}/month. Alex considers discipline, self-defense, and the satisfying snap of a well-executed kick.
